marketNews.title: Other Hot Topics to Know
marketNews.content:
1. U.S. President Donald Trump said on Tuesday (22 April) that he does not plan to fire Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell. Trump said he wants Powell to be more proactive in lowering interest rates. The rumor about Trump planning to dismiss Powell arose after National Economic Council Director Kevin Hassett said last week that Trump was studying whether he could fire Powell.
2. Bank Indonesia on Wednesday (23 April) decided to keep the BI Rate at 5.75%, with the deposit facility and lending facility also maintained at 5% and 6.5% respectively. The decision was in line with consensus expectations.
3. Bank Indonesia reported that bank credit growth slowed to 9.16% year-on-year in 1Q25 (versus 10.3% YoY in the first two months of 2025), below the 2025 target range of 11-13% YoY. Investment credit grew 13.36% YoY, consumer credit 9.32% YoY, and working-capital credit 6.51% YoY. Sharia financing grew 9.18% YoY and MSME credit grew 1.95% YoY.
4. The IMF cut its global growth forecasts for 2025 and 2026 to 2.8% and 3.0% respectively, down from 3.3% for both years in the January 2025 outlook. The IMF also lowered Indonesia’s 2025-2026 growth projections to 4.7% from the previous 5.1%.
5. President Trump said on Tuesday (22 April) that the United States will set its own terms if China does not agree to a trade deal, though he gave no further details. He added that U.S. tariffs on Chinese imports would be significantly reduced after a deal, but not to zero.
6. The Malaysian Palm Oil Council said on Tuesday (22 April) that demand for crude palm oil from China and India is expected to rise because current CPO prices of 3,900 ringgit per ton are relatively reasonable compared with competing commodities. On Wednesday (23 April), Indian CPO traders told Reuters that India is increasing CPO purchases as prices are cheaper than soybean oil.
7. Indonesia’s Energy and Mineral Resources Minister Bahlil Lahadalia claimed on Wednesday (23 April) that Zhejiang Huayou Cobalt will replace LG Energy Solution as the strategic investor in the joint electric-vehicle battery project with the Indonesian government. He said the project’s groundbreaking is planned for the end of 2025 and that there will be no change to the basic plan.
8. National Economic Council member Agus Puji Prasetyono said on Tuesday (22 April) that Indonesia’s first nuclear power plant is designed with an initial capacity of two units of 250 MW each, with priority locations in West Kalimantan, Bangka-Belitung, Southeast Sulawesi and Halmahera. The plant will be directly controlled by the government with a government-to-government international partnership. The minister previously said the plant is targeted to start operating in 2030-2032.
9. Tesla CEO Elon Musk said on Tuesday (22 April) that he will start reducing his involvement with the U.S. Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) in May 2025. The comment came as Tesla’s 1Q25 operations deteriorated, with vehicle sales down 20% YoY and net profit falling 71% YoY. BBC reported that Musk’s political involvement has triggered protests and a boycott of Tesla cars.

marketNews.title: Mandala Multifinance Dividend and Bonus Plans
marketNews.content: Mandala Multifinance announced plans to distribute a 2024 dividend of 310 billion rupiah (116 rupiah per share), representing a 60% dividend payout ratio and an implied dividend yield of 3.4% as of Wednesday (23 April). The cum-date for the regular market and negotiation is set for 28 April 2025, with payment scheduled for 22 May 2025. The company also plans a bonus issue with a ratio of 1,000 new shares for every 867.8 existing shares, with the same cum-date and payment dates.

tickerNews.title: Bank Central Asia reports 1Q25 net profit up 9.8% YoY, in line with expectations
tickerNews.content:
Bank Central Asia (BBCA) recorded a net profit of 14.1 trillion rupiah in 1Q25, up 9.8% year-on-year (YoY) and 2.8% quarter-on-quarter (QoQ), roughly in line with expectations (24% of the 2025 consensus estimate). Net profit growth was driven by solid operational performance: Net Interest Income (NII) rose 7% YoY and operating expenses grew only 3% YoY, resulting in Pre-provision Operating Profit (PPOP) increasing 10% YoY. Asset quality deteriorated, raising concerns.

1. Credit growth begins to moderate. Total credit grew 13% YoY in 1Q25 (vs. 14% YoY in 2024), largely due to a surge in short-term money-market loans. Excluding these, credit grew about 10% YoY, approaching management’s 2025 guidance of 6-8% YoY. CASA grew 8% YoY, supporting NII growth of 7% YoY with a NIM of 5.8%, matching guidance. CASA ratio reached 82.9% in 1Q25, up both annually and quarterly. Management indicated a more cautious lending stance, expecting credit growth to moderate through 2025, offset by higher loan yields and potential loan repricing.

2. Asset quality deteriorates. Non-performing loans (NPL) rose to 2% in 1Q25 (vs. 1.9% in 1Q24 and 1.8% in 4Q24). Loan-at-risk (LAR) increased to 6% quarterly (vs. 6.6% in 1Q24 and 5.3% in 4Q24). Cost of credit (CoC) reached 0.5% (vs. 0.4% in 1Q24 and -0.1% in 4Q24), above the 2025 guidance of 0.3%. The NPL rise is linked to borrowers in the textile sector, while LAR growth stems from restructuring of mineral-sector borrowers, expected to complete by 2Q25. Management considers asset quality still manageable and does not plan to raise the CoC guidance for the year.

3. Planned collaboration with BP Tapera in a public-housing program. Management said the partnership will be executed cautiously and gradually. The program offers decent margins after accounting for BP Tapera subsidies, but BBCA will be selective, focusing on housing projects with good ecosystem/infrastructure. BBCA is also open to a bullion-banking program, pending careful calculation due to gold price volatility and technical readiness.

Key Takeaway: BBCA’s 1Q25 performance remains solid. Investors should watch (i) the success of loan repricing to offset slower credit growth and (ii) asset-quality developments amid heightened uncertainty. Direct exposure to sectors exporting to the United States represents about 2% of total credit.

tickerNews.title: LPPF projects 1Q25 pro-forma net profit above Rp600 billion
tickerNews.content: Matahari Department Store (LPPF) clarified to the IDX that it projects 1Q25 pro-forma net profit of more than 600 billion rupiah, equivalent to 72% of 2024 net profit and 89% of 2023 net profit. This implies a net-profit growth of at least 84% YoY and 192% QoQ for 1Q25. The clarification followed LPPF’s plan to distribute a 2024 dividend of approximately 677.5 billion rupiah at the end of April 2025, even though cash and cash equivalents at the end of 2024 were only 399 billion rupiah. LPPF also stated that after dividend distribution, it expects to maintain positive equity in 2Q25. The company projects 2Q25 pro-forma net profit to remain positive, without further detail (vs. 2Q24 net profit of 300 billion rupiah).

tickerNews.title: MEDC announces share buyback up to 240 million shares
tickerNews.content: Medco Energi Internasional (MEDC) plans to conduct a share buyback of up to 240 million shares (0.95% of outstanding) with a funding allocation of up to 408 billion rupiah between 4 June 2025 and 3 June 2026. The plan will be discussed at the General Meeting of Shareholders on 3 June 2025. Previously, MEDC announced a buyback of up to 407 million shares (1.62%) with funding of up to 820 billion rupiah from 26 March to 25 June 2025, following the OJK’s relaxation of buyback rules to support market stability. The combined maximum buyback funding for MEDC reaches approximately 1.2 trillion rupiah.

tickerNews.title: SMGR reports 1Q25 cement sales volume decline
tickerNews.content: Semen Indonesia (SMGR) recorded cement sales volume of 2.6 million tonnes in March 2025, down 17% YoY and 14% month-on-month (MoM), reflecting the Idulfitri holiday effect. Consequently, 1Q25 total cement sales volume was 8.6 million tonnes, a 6.6% YoY decline. March’s volume drop was driven by weaker sales from Indonesian facilities, which delivered 2.5 million tonnes (-17% YoY, -16% MoM). Bulk cement sales contributed 30.6% of total March sales (vs. 28% in February 2025) and 28.5% for the full 1Q25 period.

tickerNews.title: KEJU approves 2024 dividend and plans new plant
tickerNews.content: Mulia Boga Raya (KEJU) shareholders approved a 2024 dividend of 73.12 billion rupiah, or 13 rupiah per share, representing a 49.8% dividend payout ratio and an implied dividend yield of 2.2% as of Wednesday (23 April). The cum-date and regular-market trading date have not been announced; payment is scheduled for 23 May 2025. CEO Jeffry Halim said the company targets double-digit sales growth in 2025, supported by new product launches starting in 2Q25, market expansion, and strengthened distribution channels. KEJU also plans to build a new production facility in Sumedang, West Java, costing approximately 691.6 billion rupiah, with an annual capacity of 45,249 tonnes. Construction will start in 2025 and is expected to be completed by 2028. Currently, KEJU operates a single plant with a capacity of 33,064 tonnes per year.

tickerNews.title: HEAL approves 2024 dividend
tickerNews.content: Medikaloka Hermina (HEAL) shareholders approved a 2024 dividend of 161 billion rupiah, or 10.5 rupiah per share, representing a 30.1% dividend payout ratio and an implied dividend yield of 1% as of Wednesday (23 April). The cum-date and payment date have not been announced.

tickerNews.title: BFIN signs credit facility agreement with BBCA
tickerNews.content: BFI Finance Indonesia (BFIN) signed a credit facility agreement worth 2.8 trillion rupiah with Bank Central Asia (BBCA). The facility consists of a 2 trillion rupiah installment loan (tenor 3 years) for working-capital needs, and an extension of a multi-facility credit line of 800 billion rupiah.

tickerNews.title: BNLI reports 1Q25 net profit decline
tickerNews.content: Bank Permata (BNLI) posted a 1Q25 net profit of 789 billion rupiah, down 2.3% YoY but up 1% QoQ, pressured by provision expenses that rose to 628 billion rupiah (+36% YoY, +88% QoQ). Pre-provision Operating Profit grew 9.2% YoY and 23% QoQ. Net Interest Income (NII) was relatively stable at 2.5 trillion rupiah (+1.6% YoY, -3.2% QoQ), with Net Interest Margin (NIM) falling to 4.16% (vs. 4.34% in 2024 and 4.37% in 1Q24). Financing growth (including Sharia) slowed to 6% YoY (vs. 8.9% YoY in 2024 and 13.6% YoY in 1Q24).

tickerNews.title: TLDN signs agreement to acquire PT Cipta Davia Mandiri
tickerNews.content: Teladan Prima Agro (TLDN) signed an agreement to acquire all shares of PT Cipta Davia Mandiri, a palm-oil plantation company, for a transaction value of approximately 160-210 billion rupiah. The acquisition will increase TLDN’s planted area from about 60,400 hectares to roughly 63,500 hectares, as PT Cipta Davia Mandiri manages around 3,100 hectares of oil-palm plantations.

tickerNews.title: BALI plans private placement of new shares
tickerNews.content: Bali Towerindo Sentra (BALI) intends to conduct a private placement of up to approximately 393 million new shares (10% of the capital), which would result in a dilution effect of up to 9.09%. The issue price and prospective investors have not been disclosed. Proceeds will be used to partially or fully repay existing debt and for capital expenditures. The plan will be discussed at the Extraordinary General Meeting of Shareholders on 25 April 2025.
